channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024120272
item.description:
Report E-2024120272

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-07T00:48:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-27
  • City: MOSHEIM
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Holston Gases, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 127250
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver had been making propane deliveries during the remnants of Hurricane Helene. Weather conditions were rainy with very high gusty winds. Driver stated that heavy wind gust caught the truck and pushed the truck toward the shoulder of the roadway. Right side tires dropped off the asphalt and when the driver corrected truck proceeded to overturn in the roadway and rolled coming to a stop on its side. Impact from the rollover damage one of the vapor return valves on the back of the truck and it started leaking propane. Area was secured when law enforcement arrived at the scene. Roadway was closed due to leaking propane. Fire Department and Greenville TN Hazmat team also responded to the site. Response team connected a vapor hose to the truck and routed it away from the truck so that vapor could be flared off to reduce the vapor pressure in the tank. Once the vapor pressure the was reduced the leak subsequently stopped so that the truck could be returned to its wheels and towed from the site.

item.title: Report E-2024120067
item.description:
Report E-2024120067

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-06T00:41:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-05
  • City: KENDALL
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AmeriGas Propane LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 91217
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AmeriGas cargo tank vehicle (bobtail) was traveling west on Roosevelt Highway in Kendell, NY. A 3rd party motorcycle entered the roadway at an intersection directly in front the AmeriGas vehicle. The AmeriGas vehicle did not have a stop sign and had the right of way. The motorcycle entering the intersection had a stop sign from the side road. The AmeriGas vehicle swerved left into the east bound lane to avoid impact with the motorcycle. As the AmeriGas vehicle swerved to the left, the left side wheel left the roadway which led the vehicle into an oncoming tree. The AmeriGas vehicle impacted the tree head-on with the left front corner of the vehicle. Subsequently, the vehicle spun around and rolled over 360 degrees across the roadway, coming to rest back on the wheels. The rollover damaged the rear deck of the vehicle which resulted in breaking a vapor return pipe off at the cargo tank. Propane vapor was released from the cargo tank through the vapor piping connection port. The port had a back check valve installed but it did not set due to damage from the impact. Emergency responders (fire company personnel) ultimately were able to stop the leakage by tapping and manipulating the back check valve to make it set. The driver of the AmeriGas vehicle suffered injuries in the cab of the truck during the rollover and was hospitalized. The 3rd party motorcyclist fled the scene.

  • Description: On January 31, 2025, four (4) 1-gallon pails of paint were damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remove all released material from the trailer. All waste was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: Package was found on a van line with an exterior stain visible on the cardboard packaging. Upon inspection by QA, it was found that the stain was caused by the contents leaking internally. Three of the four plastic bottles contained in the outer box had loose caps, which allowed their contents to partially spill during transport. There was no sign of damage by dropping, crushing or other mishandling which might have caused the caps to loosen. The leak was confined to the origin package - no other packages were affected, and QA was able to remove the package from the sort before any employees came in contact with the leaking substance.

  • Description: On January 27, 2025, one (1) 1-gallon pail of UN1789 was damaged by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized granular absorbents and hand tools to remove all released material from the dock floor. LSH containerized the damaged pail in one (1) 5-gallon pail and all other debris into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to a forklift accident during unloading that resulted in the drum being punctured. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent material and containerized it into two (2) 5-gallon poly drums. The 55-gallon drum of product was placed in one (1) 85-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2025011309
item.description:
Report X-2025011309

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-04T06:26:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-30
  • City: MARION
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 25200
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: I was notified that intermodal tank SNEU144870 was leaking from the bottom and there was a strong odor around the tank. Response contractor E3 was sent to investigate. Upon arrival, the E3 supervisor inspected the intermodal tank and was unable to determine where the release was coming from. He stated that the product was releasing from the jacket at three locations and that he believed there was a failure in the tank somewhere. I had E3 contain the release using granular absorbent under the trailer then order a frack tank, a vacuum truck and the necessary materials to transfer the tank if needed. I began to respond with an estimated 4 hour travel time, arriving at about 0300. While driving I obtained a waybill, total trace and made contact with the shipper, Schneider National. I spoke with a representative from Schneider and advised him of the issue. The Schneider representative advised that they have had issues with these type of tanks, beginning with the numbers 144, having cracks in the tank and leaking product through the jacket. This tank, SNEU144870 fit the description. Schneider and I began making plans to transfer the product to another Schneider tank. At about 0300 I arrived and inspected the tank. As found by E3, the valves and fittings were secure but there was obvious product dripping from three locations underneath from seams in the jacket. At about 0915, Schneider tank SNEU 145278 arrived on site and we transferred the turpentine from the 144870 to it. The Schneider contact and I discussed pulling pieces of the jacket off of the tank in order to allow product inside to drip out at a quicker pace. After the transfer I removed about three square feet of fiberglass jacket and saturated insulation, allowing the majority of product that was still there to drip leak out. I could see no obvious release points. Once it was done dripping we placed absorbent pads in the holes so that Schneider could schedule moving the tank from the UP yard.

  • Description: UNDECLARED HAZMAT PACKAGE CAME FROM LOADSIDE WET, TORN AND RETAPED. DAMAGED DURING OVERHEAD SORTATION. LIMITED QUANTITY MARKING OBSCURED BY SHIPPING LABEL. ONE BOTTLE MISSING. THREE BOTTLES LEAKED FROM CAPS OFF OR LOOSE. ALL GOODS SOILED. SPILL COLLECTED WITH ABSORBENT MATERIALS. PACKAGE PLACED IN HAZMAT BAG LINED TOTE.

item.title: Report X-2025011283
item.description:
Report X-2025011283

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-04T06:26:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-28
  • City: SOMERVILLE
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDED TO AN AIR STYROFOAM PACKAGE THAT WAS COLD TO THE TOUCH AND HEARD THE SOUND OF SOMETHING ROLLING AROUND INSIDE THE BOX. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED LESS THAN ONE POUND OF DRY ICE PELLETS COOLING DNA SAMPLES FOR RESEARCH. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING USED TO COOL THE DNA SAMPLES. THE TRACKING NUMBER APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN USED ONCE ALREADY FOR A PREVIOUS BOSTON, MASSACHUSETTS TO EUGENE, OREGON SHIPMENT IN JANUARY 2025. THIS PACKAGE IS A RETURN SERVICE PACKAGE THAT WAS SHIPPED FROM BOSTON, MASSACHUSETTS ON 28-JAN-2025 USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 863W29, PLASMIDSAURUS, 1850 MILLRACE DR SUITE 200, EUGENE OR 97403-2095. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report X-2025011298
item.description:
Report X-2025011298

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-04T06:26:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-28
  • City: Longview
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Union Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: ***Upon notification, I contacted Code 3 to respond with a crew and I was enroute. I was advised by yard personnel that the cloud was on the top of the car and would "cycle", starting and stopping, and all personnel were clear of the area and there was no movement in the yard, except for the mainline. Upon Code 3 arrival, the car was assessed and determined to have a PRD instead of a rupture disc. The leak was coming from the liquid connection flange, there was no cloud and was wisping out faintly. Code 3 exited the car and updated me. I contacted Reagent Chemical and advised him of the incident and was provided photos of how the flange should look with a gasket visible between the red and black spacers. Code 3 climbed the car and completed a more thorough inspection and found that the liquid flange bolts were easily turned by hand and no gasket was visible. The bolts were tightened and the off gassing slowed. There was moisture in the air which reacted with the HCL vapor and created a pH of 1 on top of the liquid line. The car was decontaminated with soda ash and water and the off gassing stopped. The car was moved to the Rip track, yard operations resumed, and there was no off gassing during the move. The air flange was removed to check for pressure and a vacuum was on the car. Then the liquid flange and spacer was removed, no gasket was installed, so a neoprene gasket was installed, and the liquid flange and spacer reinstalled. No further issues. Reagent Chemical sent a certified repair personnel out the afternoon of 1/29/25, installed a new gasket, checked the car for other issues, and prepped the car for Home Shop. Car is still in HZ hold.

  • Description: On 01/15/2025 at approximately 1130, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 326185 at the ramp facility in Anchorage, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box containing one item labeled as a lithium battery pack. The shipment was labeled "lithium batteries contained in equipment" and displayed a partially obliterated Battery hazard label. Further inspection revealed that the commodity is a battery pack and was improperly classified. The package was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, as it does not have required markings, labeling, and paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report X-2025011311
item.description:
Report X-2025011311

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-04T06:26:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-30
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 18000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Monday, December 30, 2024, a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be leaking from tank car # SHQX 70681 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Waterloo Yard Master who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location for mitigation. The contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV handle was disengaged and pinned upon initial inspection). During an attempt to remove the BOV Cap for inspection the leak increased. Cap was tightened and the BOV valve was inspected. The BOV valve handle was cycled exposing the valve was in the open position. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. The BOV cap gasket was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, CN emergency response contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

item.title: Report X-2025011249
item.description:
Report X-2025011249

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-04T06:26:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-30
  • City: ARCADIA
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FIRST CLASS SERVICES, INCORPORATED
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 169100
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On 12-30-2024 at 1420 hours central time I was notified by our driver that he had overturned his truck while pulling a load of Creosote. He was traveling south on Missouri Hwy 21, near Arcadia, MO, and when negotiating a left curve traveled partially off the west edge of roadway, onto a soft shoulder. In an attempt to regain control, he overcorrected, lost control and overturned onto the passenger side. The rear head fastened to the side wall of tanker (231) wall ruptured, causing more than 30,000 lbs. of material to leak onto the ground, and continued to leak for approximately five hours. The commodity being transported was Creosote, UN 3082 a Class 9 hazard. Emergency services, Pilot Knob Fire Protection District, Missouri Hwy Patrol, and Missouri DOT Hazmat Team (MDOTHT) arrived on scene. The Missouri state EPA was contacted, and I spoke with Sharon Kennedy and Greg Dillon informing them of all updates. I contacted the National Response Center (NRC) to report on the chemical spill and was provided an incident number (1420166). In addition, I was contacted by Liam Hazen, who is the disaster coordinator for the MODNR Environmental Emergency Response Section. He provided a list of hazardous material contractor cleanup teams. At approximately 1720 hours central I contacted Environmental Restoration LLC; an environmental clean-up team located near St Louis and spoke with their representative, William Lieneke, and he accepted the agreement to conduct the cleanup. Upon arriving on scene, William Lieneke made an evaluation and operated an excavator to build a berm to block the creosote from draining into a nearby stream. Lieneke has filed with the state to obtain the required permits to initiate the removal and disposal of the Creosote. At approximately 0149 hours Mr. Lieneke informed me he received authority from the state DNR representative to turn the truck and trailer from the side to the upright position. Trailer (231) was no longer leaking material due to hardening. At approximately 0410 hours the remaining Creosote was pumped off the damaged tanker (231) and onto a replacement tanker and truck. The remaining material was then transported back to the facility of origin, Omaha Track located in Granite City, Illinois.

  • Description: On January 23, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1791 was punctured in transit and released approximately one-half (0.5) gallon of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remove the released product. All waste was containerized in one (1) 15-gallon drum and the damaged drum was placed in one (1) 95-gallon overpack.

item.description:
Report E-2025010404

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-01T00:52:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-22
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 22, 2025 while conducting a site walk at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Henderson, CO an employee noticed free liquid around the bung of a drum that was loaded onto a trailer for outbound shipment. Approximately 3 ounces of UN3264 Waste Corrosive Liquid, Acidic, Inorganic, n.o.s. (nitric acid, sulfuric acid), 8, II, RQ (D002) released from the top bung of a drum (1H1) due to liquid expansion during freezing weather conditions. The container was removed from the trailer and was set aside to be overpacked. The impacted area was cleaned by Veolia personnel. No employee exposure or injury was reported.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4998
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0745 ET, Danny Mabry with Circle K store # 4703699 notified ERTS of a premium gasoline release located in Murfreesboro, TN. It was reported that approximately 30 gallons released from Fuel South Express due to overfill. The release impacted concrete only. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. ERTS proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. At 0920 on 1/9/25 HEPACO arrived onsite to the gasoline release. The gasoline that spilled impacted a 60' x 5' area on the asphalt parking lot. Oil dry is already placed down on the spill. The 30 gallon spill estimate is accurate. HEPACO worked on sweeping up the oil dry and will apply more after. HEPACO generated 2 55-gallon metal drums of gasoline impacted absorbents

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 01/06/2025 trailer 286454L arrived into BTR from MOB at 23:11 containing the 3 drum shipment on pro# 408307927. The trailer was set up for stripping at 23:30. On 01/07/2025 at 00:42, the shipment was moved& scanned to trailer 400195, located in door 25, by employee 53441. Approximately at 01:30 on 01/07/2025 trailer 400195 was being stripped for the Inbound operation. The employee stripping the trailer could smell the very strong odor of the chemical in the trailer. It was determined that one of the three drums had a fork hole in it& was Leaking. Safety was contacted& the proper channels were contacted from there. Louisiana State Police arrived on site& the in house clean up was performed. All items will be disposed of accordingly. After reviewing the cameras, considering the chemical is very thick& did not leave a trail. It was not determined if the order came into BTR Leaking. If the order was punctured during the initial off-loading of 286454L, or if the drum was punctured while off-loading 400195.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: This customer has a process in place where we scan multiple items on the trailer and customer set up before a lock code is given to unlock the fill line to be able to deliver. If that process isn't followed the driver is to call in and go through some manual verifications. That didn't happen and the unload should not have happened. Additionally a customer rep unlocked the fill line for him further bypassing protocols and they knew there was too much product for the tank to hold and that it would be a partial unload. The rep was going to tell him when to shut down. Ultimately that communication didn't happen and 3-4 gallons overflowed the tank down the sides and into the containment area. The rep rinsed down the sides of the tank into the containment drain.

item.title: Report E-2024120147
item.description:
Report E-2024120147

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-01T00:52:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-03
  • City: PARIS
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ROISSY, FRANCE, ONE AIR PACKAGE FROM CANADA TO FRANCE WAS BEING LOADED ONTO A PALLET FOR THE FINAL DELIVERY DESTINATION WHEN AN EXPLOSIVE SOUND WAS HEARD FOLLOWED BY SMOKE EMITTING FROM THE PACKAGE. THE FACILITY WAS PROMPTLY EVACUATED FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE HALF HOUR. THE LOCAL FIRE BRIGADE AND AIRPORT POLICE, AIR TRANSPORT GENDARMERIE (GTA) RESPONDED TO THE EVENT. PACKAGE INSPECTION REVEALS ONE ECO COUNTER URBAN POST (PEOPLE COUNTING SYSTEM) CONTAINING AN INSTALLED LITHIUM METAL BATTERY. THERE IS EVIDENCE OF A THERMAL LITHIUM BATTERY EVENT HAVING OCCURRED AS EVIDENT BY THE CHARRING AND BURNING MARKS ON THE DEVICE. THE PACKAGE WAS CONFISCATED BY THE GENDARMERIE DES TRANSPORTS AERIENS (GTA) FOR ANALYSIS. ONE EMPLOYEE HAD RINGING IN THE EARS AND WAS SENT TO THE HOSPITAL FOR EVALUATION. THE EMPLOYEE WAS RELEASED AND GIVEN THREE SICK LEAVE DAYS. THE PACKAGE WAS A RETURN SERVICE PACKAGE SHIPPED FROM CANADA TO THE PRODUCT OWNER IN FRANCE. THE OWNER OF THE UPS ACCOUNT IS 82F81F, ECO COMPTEUR, 4 RUE CHARLES BOURSEUL, LANNION FRANCE 22300. THE PACKAGE ENTERED THE NETWORK ON 18-NOV AND WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT YYZ TO SDF, SDF TO PHL, AND PHL TO CDG. THE PACKAGE ARRIVED IN CDG ON 20-NOV AND WAS NOT RELEASED FROM CUSTOMS UNTIL 02-DEC. NRC REPORT WAS MADE ON 06-DEC AS REQUIRED 171.15, NRC 1418132.
